Sure, here's an example of a story that effectively uses setting to convey its themes and time period: 

"A Rose for Emily" by William Faulkner. 

The story is set in a fictional town in the southern United States during the late 1800s and early 1900s. The story's themes of isolation, decay, and the decline of traditional values are conveyed through a detailed description of the setting. 

The decaying mansion is described as being old and rundown, with an unkempt garden, and a strong odor of decay permeating the area. This setting reinforces the themes of decay and isolation. Additionally, the absence of modern technologies, such as cars or telephones, helps to reinforce the time period of the story. 

The story also reflects the changing social dynamics of the time, specifically the declining power of the traditional upper-class southern family. The dilapidated house and isolated setting represent the decline of the aristocratic family and their inability to adapt to the new social norms. 

Overall, "A Rose for Emily" is an excellent example of how the setting can be used to convey themes and time period in a story.
